newsitem.title: GHANA: Canadian firm projects new Ghana gold mine.
newsitem.headline: Canadian firm projects new Ghana gold mine.

text.p: A Canadian mining firm has high hopes of opening Ghana's first underground gold mine for 40 years but has put back a pre-feasibility study until next year to allow time for further test drillings.
Nevsun Resources Ltd said that one year after starting drilling on its Kubi concession just south of Ashanti Goldfields' Obuasi mine results were very encouraging.
"We believe that Kubi has the potential to be the first new underground mine in Ghana in 40 years," the company's vice-president for exploration, Nick Laffoley, told Reuters.
Most gold mining in Ghana is open cast.
Annual production of the mine would be in excess of 100,000 ounces of gold, he predicted.
The pre-feasibility study, postponed from Q4 1996, will be carried out by Canadian Mineral Exploration Ltd of Vancouver.
"We needed more time. We realised that we are still a long way off finding the edges of the ore body. We tested so far only 2 km of the 7 km target there is to be tested," Laffoley said.

Based in Vancouver, Nevsun Resources Ltd is listed on the Toronto stock exchange. This month it raised $30 million -- for further exploration -- on the exchange without issuing warrants, Laffoley said.
"I know there are a lot of promising projects in Ghana but nobody has such a steep dipping vein which is showing such good continuity as we are seeing," he added.
Nevsun owns 90 percent of the 23 sq km Kubi concession, Ghana's government owns 10 percent.
Drilling in Kubi started in the third quarter of 1995.
"There is secondary quartz veining with some visible gold. It is not refractory, that means...we can just use simple metallurgical treatment," said Laffoley.
Preliminary testing (grinding and leaching with cyanide) gave recoveries in excess of 90 percent, he added.
Nevsun has three rigs on the concession, which is near good roads, a railway, a main electrical power line and a mining town.
